content.description: Face past 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
Climb cracks up the front face of the boulder up to the small roof. Pull over the roof on good jams. Straightforward, fun, and on perfect rock. If only it weren't so short!
content.location: Near the left side of El Gaucho buttress are two large boulders at the base. The right of these contains the route Puppy Woof. It is easily identified as a striking splitter through a small roof.

content.description:
Great shallow crack and chickenhead climbing.

Pitch 1:  climb up cracks traversing to easier knobs if desired.  Climb up far enough (passing above large shrub to the right) but still below the lower angle face full of knobs to the right (far side of the left facing corner/crack).  Build a gear belay.

Pitch 2:  climb up and over to crack, place pro, then step over the corner to the right onto the face loaded with big chickenheads.  Sling knobs, and, dance on up.  Can traverse to the right and back left on a line of knobs to keep the grade a bit lower.  In 60 or more feet, clip a bolt.  Climb up and trend left to the shallow and steeper ridge crest and pass the steeper section by slinging another knob.  Step up, look up and to the right above a low angle crescent cut out, and clip the last bolt.  Milk lower angle friction weaknesses to the top of the slab.  Find anchor towards the steeper wall just above the rappel back into the gully behind the wall (sling in pinch).

Descent:  single rope rappel back into the gully.  Follow gully down, take a left and either do a kinda sketchy downclimb on the climber's right of the gully, or, rappel from one of the large pine trees to gain the base of the route.

Note:  we didn't notice the "tunnel" mentioned in the guidebook and other route descriptions.  Wondering if recent rockfall has buried it...?
content.protection: Standard rack (set of stoppers and cams to 3 camalot or equivalent).  2 lead bolts on the second pitch.  Take slings for knobs.  No fixed anchor on route.  Anchor at top is behind large flake (think, "where would I put a rappel anchor?") and is slings on a pinch (not able to see the slings from the top of the slab:  walk around to behind the flake above the most reasonable place for a rappel).
content.location: Left side of the El Gaucho formation.  Climb up to the more obvious "Puppy Woof" (either 3rd class behind to the left or climb PW) and start on the right side of the tree and rubbly narrow gully.  Can also be started by going up the open left facing corner of Gay Caballero and traversing in on the horizontal crack only 20 or so feet from the start of that route.

climbs.name: Inknobvious Line
climbs.fa: Mark Uphus, Bill Cramer and Chuck Bowker,  June 1990

content.description: One long pitch variation that joins El Diablo route at its first belay. Interesting face climbing on knobs.
content.protection: Light rack, bolts and slings for knobs.
content.location: At a black stain left of a left facing arch at the center of the El Gaucho Wall look for a bolt. Face climb straight up to the top of the arch. Tend left then up a sea of knobs to a bolt belay. Continue up El Diablo route to the top.

content.description: This route starts as a left leaning finger and hand crack (5.8). Eventually the crack peters out into a knobby face. Make a few exciting moves on knobs up into a flared water groove, and follow this (5.9) to the top. A wee bit dicey.
content.location: Near the left side of El Gaucho buttress are two large boulders at the base. The right of these contains the route Puppy Woof. Scramble up the gully in between these boulders to reach the base of the route. Above you, the arete of the buttress drops down right at the top of the gully. Gay Caballero starts right above you, but to reach the ledge you start off, tunnel left under the left boulder and then up, then come back to the right side of the ledge. To contrive an extra twenty feet of climbing, start the crack right at the top of the gully instead of on the ledge. If you do this, a 60m rope will not reach the summit! I learned the hard way. A 70m would have been fine, though.

content.description:
This route is in the center of the formation. It starts about 50 feet to the right of El Gaucho.

Scramble up some blocks to a high first bolt. Climb up and left past 5 bolts and then traverse right. Don't keep going left here or you'll end up on El Bolo. There is also a much harder variation to the right of this line called El Polo Loco (5.12a).

Climb up easier slab past a couple more bolts to a roof. Pull the roof on big holds, then up more slab to the anchors.

Rap with 2 ropes, or swing right to the anchors on Cuban Slide to get down with 1 rope.
content.protection: A few pieces to 2" and 9 bolts. Bring some runners to help with rope drag.
